Ask HN: Tabnine blatantly lying about Eclipse Support?
text:
So unfortunately I'm currently still bound to Eclipse as an IDE since I'm bound to some plugins our Software Vendor made (A custom visual editor).

After looking for a Github Copilot / AI code completion solution for Eclipse I came across tabnine hoping it would help me.

The thing is though; It's all smoke and mirrors. Its everywhere on their site, but even their install guide is fake: https://www.tabnine.com/install/eclipse

Contacted Support but they stated it isn't supported and they aren't working on it..

Are there any people on HN that know when this will be released?

Ask HN: SMS Surveys for Research?
text:
Does anyone have experience participating in or proctoring surveys/polls through text message? I'm interested in hearing about your experience. The good, bad, ugly, and outcome.

I'm finishing a custom SMS API and thought it might benefit research universities who routinely conduct surveys and polls. However, I've not seen a study that leveraged SMS surveys.

Show HN: Rapidly prototype and launch LLM Apps
text:
BerriAI is like Retool for LLM Apps. It makes it easy for you to ingest data from Documents, PDFs, Google Docs, Notion, Coda, Excel Sheets, GitHub Code Repos, Jira, Zendesk, PostgreSQL, Datadog and Snowflake. Empower your developers to quickly spin up ChatGPT apps for your organization data through our data connectors, 1-click production deploy, LLM Agent Initializer and Tool Builder. We provide developers with ready made templates for your selected data sources and allow you to write custom data chunking, vectorizing code and build your own LLM Agents.

What can you do with Berri? 1. Build a chat/search interface to ask questions about your Documents, Knowledge Base 2. Create a CRM tools to generate outreach messages based on LinkedIn Profiles 3. Build tools to query your database / data warehouses / Application Metrics in natural language (example queries: What is our Monthly ARR? Which transactions are anomalies) 4. Create Tools to automate customer support requests using your Docs, past ZenDesk, Jira Tickets as a knowledge base.

title: Ask HN: Any startups not using Public Cloud?
text:
There has been a lot of talk recently about the Public Cloud premium, how expensive it can get to run something in the 3 Big Cloud Providers, and generally to be cautious about it. Yet, when I look around, I fail to find success stories of companies that started/stayed outside of the public cloud. (To be clear, I'm constraining it to 2015+, when public cloud really picked up. If your company started before that, you didn't have much of an choice).

So my question is: Are there good examples of startups that have managed to successfully operate outside the public cloud in recent years? What has your experience been like?

Ask HN: What would ask Head of Recruitment at an HFT firm?
text:
We have a webinar coming up with the Head of Recruitment and a Quant Researcher (who does technical interviews).

We want to get some questions ready for them both.

We (and they) are very interested in applicants from _outside_ the (finance) industry - not just current quants and fintech people.

The Quant Researcher is actually not from the finance industry - so he has an interesting perspective.

Ask Black HN: How's it going?
text:
In light of Black History Month, I'm curious about the experience of Black folks in technical fields.

- What do you do and how did you get into it? - What challenges have you faced that seem to be pigment-based? - What improvements have you seen in your field? - What do you want to see but haven't yet? - What would help the field to get there?

This post is directed at Black people but isn't meant to exclude anyone else. When sharing something subjective, consider including your vantage point. E.g. I'm and I hope this question isn't too cringe. I felt curious about this and decided to ask.

Ask HN: Choice of HDL for an FPGA Project
text:
I am sitting in front of Vivado right now about to start writing my first module, a decoder for RISC-V. I basically want to make a full computer in the spirit of LISP machines. I know how ambitious it is but I really want to try.

I am wondering whether I should stop procrastinating and just proceed with Verilog right now, or try a more modern language like Clash or SpinalHDL first though. I do not know anything about Scala and only have a basic idea of Haskell.

People who have used an "alternative" HDL, how has your experience been? Are there any major disadvantages and pain points? Is the produced code efficient and robust? Were the readability and productivity gains worth it? What about device primitives?

Anything you could share on the matter would be appreciated!

EDIT: I decided to just get started with Verilog now, see how it goes and reconsider a rewrite along the way, which I 'll definitely do if it's worth it.
